coredata.dc:title: Monte carlo simulation and thermodynamic perturbation theory for mixtures of diatomic molecules
coredata.dc:creator: Tildesley, D.J.
Enciso, E.
Sevilla, P.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The thermodynamic properties and site—site distribution functions of mixtures of non-spherical molecules are obtained by Monte Carlo simulation. A non-spherical reference-system perturbation theory based on the RISM equation is developed to predict these results. The agreement between theory and simulation for the thermodynamic properties is encouraging. Important differences in the relative peak heights of the site—site distribution functions from theory and simulation are attributed to the role of attractive forces in determining local structure in the fluid mixtures, where the volumes of the components are similar but the well depths differ.

Introduction In this paper, we present some initial results from a study of the structural and thermodynamic properties of mixtures of linear molecules in the liquid state. Previous work in this area. which has been comprehensively re- viewed in ref. [ 1 ]. concentrates on models where the intermolecular potential in the mixture is represented by some generalized Stockmayer potential. In this class of models, the hard-core repulsion depends only on the dis- tance between two molecules. Tlie anisotropic interaction is represented by suitable terms in the multipole expan- sion. In the theory of one-component fluids, an alternative interaction site model has been extensively studied [2,3]. Tlie molecule is composed of rigidly connected force centres, which interact with centres on neighbouring mole- cules. In this way. anisotropy in the repulsion is built into the model explicitly. We shall use interaction site mod- els to study the effect of shape on the properties of molecular mixtures. Initial efforts in this area include Monte Carlo simulations of mixtures of hard dumbbells and of hard spherocylinders [4 6]. The scaled particle theory has been developed for mixtures of convex bodies [7] ,and recently the RISM equation has been solved for mix- tures of dumbbells and hard spheres [8]. We concentrate on two equimolar mixtures of diatomic Lennard-Jones molecules (DLJ). The model has a rigid linear geometry with a soft repulsive core and an attractive anisotropic dispersion interaction. These crude models are chosen to represent approximately N^/O^ and COs/C^Hg mixtures. The configurational energies, pressure and site site distribution functions (SDFs) of the mixtures are calculated using the Monte Carlo method. The "exact" data are used to test a perturbation theory based on the WCA division of the atom atom potential [9]. Previous perturbation theories for mixtures of d'ltomic molecules and atoms are based on the Barker Henderson division [10]. This theory gives the SDFs and energies of the model. Conclusions The Monie Carlo simulation technique has been used to calculate the thermodynamic properties and SDFs of two mixtures of diatomic Leonard-Jones molecules. The relative positions of the first peaks in three SDFs corre- sponding to a particular mixture are determined by the diameters of the atoms, but the relative heights of these peaks are determined by the well depths of the site site potentials. We have developed a perturbation theory based on a non-spherical reference system to predict the mixture SDFs. The tlieory gives a reasonable quantita- tive description of the fluid, showing the main peaks and rounded cusps which are typical in the SDFs of molec- ular fluids. The most likely source of error is in tlie SDFs of the reference hard-dumbbell mixtures which are ob- tained in the RISM approximation. In addition, the theoretically obtained first-peak heights are equal in magnitude, indicating the difficulty of tlie tlieory in coping with the effect of attractive interactions between the components of the mixture. The role of dttiactive forces in determining local structure has already been observed in the computer simulation of mix- lines of Lennard-Jones atoms [19] and square-well mixtures [20]. Since attractive forces are important in deter- mining mixture structure, simple HTA perturbation theories [9.10] for interaction site models will need to be improved using optimized cluster theory [20]. The theory predicts the configurational energies of the fluids to better than 3%. Although the pressure is not directly obtainable from the SDFs, its calculation can be effected using an additional site superposition approximation. For the mixture containing the elongated molecules, the predicted pressure agrees with the simulation to within the estimated error. This can be traced to the excellent agreement between the SDFs from theory and simulation on tlie leading side of the first peak. For tlie other mix- ture. poorer agreement between tlie simulated and predicted structure in this region gives rise to a tlieoretical pres- sure which is too positive.
